title: Amazon Suspends Police Use of Its Facial-Recognition Technology
summary: Move comes after IBM said it was curtailing its facial-recognition activities amid widespread concerns about bias. Amazon.com Inc. said it is halting law-enforcement use of its facial-recognition software, adding its voice to a growing chorus of companies, lawmakers and civil rights advocates calling for greater regulation of the surveillance technology amid widespread concern about its potential for racial bias.

title: Big Advertisers Call for Time-Shift in TV's Upfront Marketplace
summary: Procter & Gamble, Bank of America and others want to move upfront negotiations for ads in the multibillion TV market to the fall from the spring.. Big-brand advertisers and an industry trade group are calling on the television networks to delay their annual upfront ad marketplace to later in the year-a big shift in the way TV programmers and advertisers have done business for decades.

title: The Problem With Police Unions
summary: Collective bargaining protects too many bad cops from discipline.. Remember the furor in 2011 when Republican governors tried to reform collective bargaining for government workers? Well, what do you know, suddenly Democrats say public-union labor agreements are frustrating police reform. We're delighted to hear it-if they're serious.

title: Jay Powell Lets It Loose
summary: The Fed sees near-zero rates for years even as the economy rebounds.. President Trump raged against Jerome Powell a while back, but after Wednesday the Federal Reserve Chairman may be the President's version of most improved player. The Fed chief told financial markets that the central bank will keep interest rates near zero through at least 2022 while revving up bond-buying to record levels.

title: Disneyland Resort in Southern California to Begin Reopening in July
summary: Anaheim park is on similar timetable to Walt Disney World in Orlando; Disney parks have been shut down since March. LOS ANGELES-Walt Disney Co. said it aims to begin a phased reopening of its Disney land Resort in July, the latest sign that the world's largest entertainment company is joining the rest of the nation's economy in getting operations up and running again, at least in a limited form.

title: When Wisconsin's Lockdown Ended
summary: A study finds 'no evidence' that it led to Covid-19 outbreaks.. 'We're the Wild West." That's what Wisconsin Governor Tony Evers said on May 13, after the state Supreme Court threw out a stay-at-home order issued by his administration. The result, Mr. Evers added, would be "chaos" during a pandemic: "We're going to have more deaths, and it's a sad occasion for the state."

title: Covid, DNA and Blood Type
summary: Studies are finding that those with O blood are less susceptible.. Millions of Americans have taken personal DNA tests from companies like 23andMe to find out whether their genes put them at higher risk for diseases like breast and colon cancer. Now these tests are identifying people who are more likely to get sick with Covid-19.

title: Grubhub Shuns Uber for Europe's Just Eat
summary: Merger, which values Grubhub at $7.3 billion, would create a trans-Atlantic delivery giant at a time the industry is seeking scale. Grubhub Inc. agreed to combine with Europe's Just Eat Takeaway.com NV, turning its back on Uber Technologies Inc. in a surprising twist in the scramble for mergers among food-delivery companies.

title: Justice Department's Criminal Division Chief to Step Down
summary: Brian Benczkowski helped supervised the prosecution of Joaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán and an investigation into Goldman Sachs's role in a Malaysian embezzlement scheme. A senior U.S. Justice Department official who helped supervise investigations into major white-collar crime and the agency's response to the opioid crisis will depart in July, the agency said.

title: Tim Scott Leads on Police Reform
summary: The senator who once said 'it's too easy to be angry' is focused on constructive action.. Practical politics can sometimes be married to high purpose. That's the case with Sen. Tim Scott (R., S.C.), the leader of GOP efforts on police reform following the death of George Floyd.

title: Requiem for the Printing Press
summary: Local newspapers are printing their editions many miles away.. The finest moment in the finest movie about newspapers ever made-"Deadline-U.S.A." (1952)-comes in the final scene.

title: 'The Arab Winter' Review: The Dreams of Youth
summary: In U.S. foreign policy, the promotion of democracy can't override the basic logic of supporting friends and punishing enemies.. Noah Feldman, Harvard law professor and Middle East expert, is a democracy promoter who's been mugged by reality. In "The Arab Winter: A Tragedy," he analyzes the wave of popular protests that swept the Middle East in 2011. The Arab Spring, as it was optimistically called, generated a sense that democracy was spreading across the region just as it had, in previous decades, across Eastern Europe and Latin America. With the benefit of hindsight, Mr. Feldman now concedes that the Arab Spring "brought little good." A single ray of light did appear in Tunisia, but everywhere else the "heroic narrative" gave way to "something much darker."

title: The Media's Self-Censors
summary: The pre-liberal idea of settling disagreements with coercion has made a comeback in the United States.. In 1789, America's Founding Fathers, acutely aware of the political bloodbaths that had consumed Europe for centuries, created a system in which disagreements would be arbitrated by periodically allowing the public to turn their opinions into votes. The majority would win the election. Then, because political disagreement never ends, you hold more elections. Aware of the natural tendency of factions and majorities to want to suppress opposition opinion, the Founders created a Bill of Rights for all citizens, including what they called, with unmistakable clarity, "the freedom of speech."

title: Fed Officials Project No Rate Increases Through 2022
summary: Central bank says it will maintain current pace of asset purchases to sustain growth. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve officials signaled plans to keep interest rates near zero for years and said they were studying how to provide more support to a U.S. economy battered by the coronavirus and related shutdowns.

title: Tyson Foods Cooperating in Price-Fixing Probe
summary: Meat giant says it is aiding Justice Department investigation under leniency program after self-reporting its own conduct. Tyson Foods Inc., the leading U.S. chicken producer, said it is cooperating in a Justice Department price-fixing investigation under a leniency program that will allow the company to avoid criminal prosecution in exchange for aiding in the continuing probe of other poultry suppliers.

title: More Cities Ban Chokeholds, Similar Restraints in Wake of George Floyd Protests
summary: Technique that restricts breathing is controversial, including with police. A growing number of cities and states are moving to ban the use of neck holds by police following protests over the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis.

title: Trump Considers Ways to Address Police Abuse
summary: President, advisers consider options, expect to also vigorously support law enforcement. WASHINGTON-President Trump and his advisers are weighing a possible executive order or other policy actions to address abuses by police, responding to widespread public anger following the killing of George Floyd in police custody last month.

title: The Fed's Work Is Far From Done
summary: If central bankers' predictions about the economy are accurate, then stimulus will keep flowing for a lot longer. The Federal Reserve isn't as ebullient about signs of recovery in the economy as investors seem to be.

title: Private-Equity-Backed Vista Proppants Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Frac-sand supplier, brought down by coronavirus pandemic and slumping oil and gas prices, will use bankruptcy to jettison unprofitable railcar leases. Vista Proppants & Logistics LLC, a frac-sand supplier backed by investment firms First Reserve Corp. and Ares Capital Corp. , has filed for bankruptcy, saying it is facing unprecedented problems due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Nascar Bans the Confederate Flag From Its Races
summary: Carolina Panthers remove statue of franchise founder over past racist remarks. The U.S. reckoning on race hit the sports world, as Nascar banned Confederate flags at its events, and a National Football League team removed the statue of its founding owner who had been accused of racist remarks.

title: States Sue Drug Companies, Executives Over Alleged Price Fixing
summary: The lawsuit, which was filed in Connecticut, involves at least 80 skin products. The Connecticut attorney general, along with 50 other states and territories, has filed a third lawsuit against generic drug manufacturers and executives for allegedly inflating prices.

title: 24 Hour Fitness Uses Phone Calls to Cut Staff Across the U.S.
summary: Operator of more than 430 gyms has been stung as pandemic has hurt revenue. Gym chain 24 Hour Fitness Worldwide Inc. laid off an undisclosed number of employees in multiple states via a series of phone calls Wednesday, as the company struggles to address the financial impact of closures during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: It's Only the News That Fits Their Worldview
summary: The purge of senior editors at the New York Times and the Philadelphia Inquirer is easily explained. These are no longer publications of objective journalism but journals of instruction.. Regarding your editorial "Cancel Culture Journalism" (June 9): The purge of senior editors at the New York Times and the Philadelphia Inquirer is easily explained. These are no longer publications of objective journalism but journals of instruction. Their intent is to instruct their audiences what to do and what to believe, not to inform them so they can make their own decisions. Therefore anything which doesn't accord with this goal of instruction should not appear on their pages. This includes contrary opinions on the editorial pages. So the revolt in the Times's newsroom isn't surprising. "All the news that's fit to print" says it nicely. If you don't fit, we won't print.

title: Tesla Shares Soar Past $1,000 on Plan to Move Forward With Semi Truck
summary: Silicon Valley electric-car maker is in a race with rival upstart Nikola. Tesla Inc. investors pushed the auto maker's stock to more than $1,000 a share Wednesday, lifting its valuation closer to Toyota Motor Corp.'s , after Chief Executive Elon Musk told employees it was time to begin volume production of the company's long-promised, all-electric semitrailer truck.

title: Count All the Income in Making Social Policy
summary: The primary source Michael Petrilli cites uses Census money income that ignores $1.9 trillion of annual federal, state and local transfer payments to households.. Michael J. Petrilli ("The Unequal American City," op-ed, June 9) summarizes a geographic view of income inequality in America. Unfortunately, the analysis continues to rely on seriously flawed and misleading data. The primary source he cites uses Census money income that ignores $1.9 trillion of annual federal, state and local transfer payments to households. Excluded are programs like the earned-income tax credit, where beneficiaries get a check from the Treasury, food stamps, where beneficiaries buy food with government-issued debit cards and numerous other programs such as Medicare and Medicaid where government simply pays for the benefits directly. The data also exclude all the effects of $4.4 trillion in federal, state and local taxes, 61% of which are paid by the top income quintile. In short, the analysis ignores 49% of all household income.

title: Big Apple Might Have Spoiled U.S. Food-Delivery Feast
summary: Investors are hungry for food-delivery consolidation, but Wednesday's deal isn't particularly savory. Another week, another pickle for food delivery. And this meal isn't likely to be one that any investor will relish.

title: Politics Trumps Science for Medical Activists
summary: I never, ever thought that after practicing medicine for 40 years I would come across such a dangerous and irresponsible insanity as this.. Regarding your editorial "Doctors for Lockdown Discrimination" (June 8): I never, ever thought that after practicing medicine for 40 years I would come across such a dangerous and irresponsible insanity as this.

title: Let the Europeans, Mostly, Defend Germany
summary: Keeping tens of thousands of U.S. troops in Europe is so last century. Have you not heard of the European Union? Let the EU do its job and defend its members against Russian and Chinese threats.. Regarding your editorial "Retreat From Germany" (June 8): Keeping tens of thousands of U.S. troops in Europe is so last century. Have you not heard of the European Union? Let the EU do its job and defend its members against Russian and Chinese threats. The U.S. troops in Europe enable the behavior that keeps many countries from reaching 2% of GDP spending as their NATO obligation. Why bother, the U.S. is here? Your editorials are replete with examples of how government handouts influence behavior. NATO is obsolete, and its mission should be re-evaluated by the EU countries and modified as agreed upon by EU members.

summary: Wednesday's meeting was the last one under the standard-setter's current chairman, whose term ends June 30. Insurers may get even more time to implement a new rule on valuing long-term contracts, under a proposal by the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

title: Manhattan Private School Plans a Hamptons Branch
summary: Avenues school attracts parents seeking alternatives amid the coronavirus pandemic; at-home tutoring for $65,000. Avenues, a for-profit school based in Manhattan, is pitching two new ventures for families seeking flexibility and safety during the coronavirus pandemic: An outpost in the Hamptons and a service dispatching full-time teachers to students' homes.

title: Coronavirus Explosion Forecast for One Indian State
summary: State that includes New Delhi expects case count to hit 550,000 by end of July; Parisian public transport companies might not be able to pay their bills. • The U.S. coronavirus death toll passed 112,000, while reported cases topped 1.9 million, according to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University. summary: The Village Vanguard, Smalls and other clubs and organizations have begun streaming performances online-some recorded at the venues, others in artists' homes..

title: Hasan Minhaj on Telling Jokes Without a 'Safety Net'
summary: The host of Netflix's 'Patriot Act With Hasan Minhaj' sees comedians adapting their work to uncertain times. The past few months have been a blessing and a challenge for comedians. title: Stock Pickers Underperformed During Market Turmoil
summary: In the early months of 2020, most U.S. large-cap stock-picking funds lagged behind the S&P 500. Most U.S. large-cap stock-picking funds underperformed the benchmark S&P 500 during the tumultuous early months of 2020, according to new data from S&P Dow Jones Indices.

summary: 'Their Finest Hour' collects five vintage, understated World War II movies that range from speculative history to documentary realism.. But thanks to our proximity to various screens and a surfeit of material to view on them, this year is turning into something of a golden age for movie watching-even as it must be done at home and in select company.

summary: Four film scholars share fictional movies and documentaries that illuminate black culture, from the 1960s to today. Interest in documentaries and movies that tell stories of the black experience is running high as protests over the police killing of George Floyd continue and as Americans aim to learn more about race.

title: Cooler Showdown: Is Colder Beer Worth $800?
summary: In a 48-hour test, we pitted Yeti's new $800 V Series cooler against a classic Coleman that goes for just $100. YETI OWES its cult following to the Tundra cooler-and grizzly bears. In 2008 the Austin-based brand launched the premium cooler category with a lineup that now ranges from $249 to $1,300 for a 19,000-cubic-inch cooler-massive enough to keep a sport fisherman's trophy-size catch on ice. Known to be virtually indestructible, most Tundras are certified bear-resistant by the Interagency Grizzly Bear Committee-a very real thing. If a padlocked cooler survives 60 minutes of being clawed and swatted, it earns the enviable sticker.

title: U.S. Budget Deficit Widened to $399 Billion in May From $208 Billion a Year Earlier
summary: Officials said federal efforts to combat the coronavirus pandemic and related economic downturn added about $250 billion to the deficit in May, nearly $900 billion in April.. WASHINGTON-The U.S. government's budget deficit rose 92% in May from a year earlier to $399 billion, as revenues plummeted and spending surged on efforts to stem the new coronavirus pandemic and the fallout from lockdowns.

title: Did You Forget Things During Lockdown? So Did People With Superior Memories
summary: For individuals with Highly Superior Autobiographical Memory, the monotony of quarantine dulled their recall. title: The Thinking Behind Trump's Troop Cut in Germany
summary: It appeals to three sorts of pro-Trump intellectuals: neo-mercantalists, realists and neo-nationalists.. The U.S. troop presence in Germany not only deters Russian aggression; it reassures Germany's neighbors east and west that Berlin will never again disturb the peace of Europe or threaten their security.

title: How Academia Failed to Improve Police Practices
summary: Replicating good policing is less interesting to social scientists than promoting political causes in papers.. There is plenty of blame to go around for the latest civil unrest, from police unions to political leaders. But don't let academia off the hook. My fellow professors had years to figure out how to improve policing so that it better protects the lives and dignity of African-Americans. Few did so. Instead, professors have been preoccupied with obscure research topics and political causes.

title: Why Narnia Resonates More Than Ever This Summer
summary: A beloved classic, 'The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe' isn't just enthralling. It's a timely reminder that even in the darkest of seasons in America, there is relief in finding the courage to engage. IT'S JUNE in America. But it might as well be January. Frozen in place by an endless pandemic, our moods brittle as ice, pent-up frustrations erupting into anger, we still seem metaphorically gripped by winter. We are living in a sort of Narnia, the setting of C.S. Lewis's beloved 1950 children's classic "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe," a traumatized magical land where it is "always winter and never Christmas."

title: China and India Pull Back From Himalayan Standoff

summary: Resume Subscription. When coronavirus lockdowns sent Americans into a frenzy of panic buying, the bad news came almost as quickly as the good for online organic grocer Thrive Market.

title: Ulta Beauty Undertakes Review of Its 1,254 Stores
summary: Cosmetics chain is looking to renegotiate leases, move locations and close some underperforming stores. Ulta Beauty Inc., a cosmetics chain that is a staple of shopping centers across the country, is undertaking a "clean sheet" review of its stores, exploring whether to close, move or remodel its hundreds of brick-and-mortar locations in light of pressures facing retailers, including the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Chinese Sports Power Couple Issues Rare Rebuke of Communist Party
summary: Retired soccer star Hao Haidong and his wife, former badminton world champion Ye Zhaoying, are speaking out against Beijing's leadership. Two of China's most celebrated athletes have denounced the ruling Communist Party, a stunning display for a country used to seeing its sporting heroes lavish praise on authorities for their personal successes.

title: Trash Burning Ignites as World's Waste Swells
summary: The growth of incineration, buoyed by moves against landfills, raises concerns about fumes and impact on recycling efforts. The world is creating more garbage, and it is getting tougher to dispose of it. That is propelling more cities to send their trash to the incinerator.

title: Zara Owner to Close 1,200 Stores as It Outlines Post-Coronavirus Future
summary: Inditex, which also owns Massimo Dutti and Pull&Bear, to close as many as 1,200 stores in strategic shift after Covid-19. Zara-owner Inditex SA said it is permanently closing as many as 1,200 stores-16% of its global outlets-and will pivot more aggressively toward selling online, as the fast-fashion giant maps out its post-pandemic future.

title: Tested Positive for Coronavirus Antibodies? Stay Vigilant
summary: Resume Subscription. After a rocky rollout, higher-quality coronavirus antibody tests have emerged that, among other uses, are beginning to give a clearer picture of the pathogen's spread.

title: Trump Administration Sued Over Pandemic Deportation Policy
summary: Since the emergency declaration in March, migrants have been turned away at the border without a chance to apply for asylum. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration, which has used the coronavirus health emergency to expel migrants at the border without allowing them to apply for asylum, faces its first court challenge over the practice in a lawsuit filed on behalf of a 16-year-old boy.

title: After 34 Years, a Political Assassination in Europe Remains Shrouded in Mystery
summary: Sweden wraps up investigation into former Prime Minister Olof Palme's killing. STOCKHOLM-A 34-year-old investigation into the murder of Swedish Prime Minister Olof Palme is now closed, prosecutors said Wednesday. But the mystery surrounding one of postwar Europe's most prominent political killings will likely endure given that the only suspect is dead.

title: Zara's Owner Bets Crisis Will Speed Up Fashion's Big Trend
summary: Global clothing retailer Inditex is doubling down on the industry's digital transition with a plan to operate fewer, larger stores. Zara's owner has a reputation for spotting fashion trends early. Now, the world's top clothing retailer expects the Covid-19 crisis to turbocharge the shift toward e-commerce.

title: Remote Work Forever? Not So Fast, Jobs Guru Says
summary: The CEO of Adecco, one of the world's largest employment agencies, discusses the pros and cons of working from home. Alain Dehaze knows a lot about jobs, and he's not sold on remote work.

title: Home From College, Old Friends Become Protest Leaders
summary: How four 19-year-olds ended up organizing a 15,000-person march for police reform. OAKLAND, Calif.-On June 1 of last year, Josiah Jacobs stood on his high school graduation stage in a red graduation gown and a black bow tie giving the salutatorian address.

title: Grammys Tweak Rules to Address Credibility, Diversity Concerns
summary: Recording Academy changes conflict-of-interest policies, hip-hop/R&B awards amid criticism. The Grammy Awards is adjusting its rules to address concerns about its voting practices and treatment of hip-hop artists that have threatened its legitimacy.

title: Coronavirus Makes AR's Potential a Reality for Chip Makers
summary: Semiconductor and other industries embrace augmented reality after finding new uses for the visualization tool during the pandemic. Intel Corp.'s semiconductor production hit a stumbling block in March. A chip plant in Chandler, Ariz., needed work done, but the engineer for the job was stuck in Germany because of trans-Atlantic flight restrictions to combat the spread of the coronavirus.

title: A Rising China's Underclass Is Suddenly Thrust Into the Light
summary: There are no doubts that income inequality has always been an issue in China. Jobs, instead of growth, will be the focus of China's post-Covid-19 economy. The plight of the country's millions of low-income workers is highlighting the gaps in China's social safety net-and creating political fissures as well.

title: In Photos: George Floyd Funeral and Protests
summary: George Floyd, whose killing has sparked world-wide protests over racial injustice, was buried in Houston on Tuesday.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: CrossFit CEO to Exit Amid Backlash Over George Floyd Remarks
summary: Reebok, hundreds of gyms had cut ties with CrossFit after founder Greg Glassman's tweet and comments about George Floyd's killing. Greg Glassman, the founder and chief executive of CrossFit Inc., said he had decided to retire after his inflammatory remarks about the killing of George Floyd prompted sponsors and gym owners to cut ties with his company.

title: Rice Prices Spike to Highest Level Since 2011
summary: Surging demand from coronavirus lockdowns and global weather issues have dented rice availability. Rice futures spiked to their highest level in nearly nine years after the global pandemic boosted shoppers' demand for the grain.

title: What We Talk About When We Talk About CLOs
summary: The biggest risk at the moment is credit availability, not losses for big investors. When collateralized loan obligations enter the public discussion, it's usually in the context of credit risk. Perhaps the focus right now should be on something different: the supply of credit.

title: Chewy Stock May Be Overfed
summary: The business had impressive results last quarter, but its share price may have overshot even before the results were announced. Chewy was in for a treat last quarter as furry companions joined the list of items humans acquired while sheltering in place during the coronavirus pandemic. Investors seem to have overfed on the shares, though.

title: U.S.-China Struggle Puts Europe in an Awkward Bind
summary: Europe is broadly sympathetic to U.S. worries about China, but slow growth at home makes it more dependent on the emerging superpower. European attitudes to China were never far from American ones and have been getting closer. But there is one big difference: While greater economic independence from its big strategic rival is an expensive option for the U.S., it is an unaffordable one for Europe.

title: China Tries an Old Remedy to Revive Economy: Street Stalls
summary: With unemployment rising amid China's first economic contraction in four decades, Beijing is turning to sidewalk trade as a way to unleash its animal spirits. China spent much of the past two decades clamping down on street vendors in its biggest cities, part of an effort to clean up the country's image, improve food safety and hygiene and more tightly regulate commerce.

title: China's Companies Find Ways to Avoid Bond Blowups
summary: Some methods include asking creditors to wait longer for repayment or forgo the right to redeem bonds early. Chinese companies are avoiding or minimizing bond defaults, even as the economy shrinks for the first time in decades.

title: Schools to Take Hard Look at How They Teach Aspiring Cops
summary: California, Virginia to review instruction amid protests against police brutality in wake of George Floyd's killing; North Carolina adds funds for training. Community colleges around the country are embarking on reviews of how they teach future police officers, aiming to make changes at the beginning stages of law-enforcement training amid intense scrutiny of policing tactics in the U.S.

title: Coronavirus Pandemic Makes Jobless Rate Calculation Harder
summary: 'Misclassification error' caused jobless rate to be lower than it would have been otherwise, Labor Department says. The Labor Department is struggling to document accurately how many workers are unemployed in the recession caused by the coronavirus pandemic, a difficulty the government has faced during other times of rapidly changing economic conditions.

title: U.S. Sends Aircraft Carriers as China Makes Waves in the Pacific
summary: USS Ronald Reagan and USS Nimitz deployed under a new 'bubble of health' plan to prevent coronavirus outbreaks. The U.S. deployed two aircraft carrier strike groups to the Pacific under new health procedures to guard against another coronavirus outbreak, as China's military steps up its activity in the region.

title: Second Pandemic Wave Would Inflict Big Economic Cost, Says OECD
summary: A resurgence of the pandemic later this year would damp the partial recovery that is expected to take place in 2021.

title: China's Factory-Gate Deflation Accelerates
summary: Prices fall at fastest pace in more than four years as the coronavirus pandemic crushes global demand for commodities. China's industrial deflation worsened in May, with factory-gate prices falling at their fastest pace in more than four years as the coronavirus pandemic crushed global demand for commodities.

title: HBO Max Pulls 'Gone With the Wind,' While 'Cops' Gets Canceled
summary: Moves come as entertainment companies reassess their content amid nationwide protests over racial injustice and police brutality. "Gone with the Wind" was pulled from HBO Max while the long-running TV show "Cops" was outright canceled, a sign that entertainment companies are re-examining the content they offer in the wake of nationwide protests for racial justice and against police brutality.

title: Judge Hints at Potential Disciplinary Action for Prosecutors in Sanctions Case
summary: A federal prosecutor Friday asked to drop the case against Ali Sadr Hashemi Nejad, who was convicted on money-laundering and sanctions violations charges. A federal judge indicated prosecutors could face disciplinary action for allegedly failing to turn over evidence in a case that led to the conviction of an Iranian man on money-laundering and sanctions violations charges.

title: LaGuardia Airport's New Terminal Hall Set to Open Saturday
summary: Arrivals and departures hall accounts for coronavirus concerns with plexiglass screens at check-in desks, and touchless technology. LaGuardia Airport's new arrivals and departures hall at Terminal B will open Saturday despite a global pandemic that has decimated air travel.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Park by White House, Set to Reopen, Symbolizes Arc of D.C. Protests
summary: Lafayette Square, a center of demonstrations sparked by George Floyd killing, gains new significance as site of national drama. Washington's Lafayette Square, at the center of more than a week of protest prompted by George Floyd's killing, is set to reopen with a new significance, having hosted conflict and a president's law-and-order message to become a signboard of protest over police brutality and racism.

title: Electric-Truck Startup Nikola Bolts Past Ford in Market Value
summary: Shares skyrocket after chairman takes aim at pickup market on Twitter. The market value of Nikola Corp. , a little-known electric-truck startup that went public last week, has surged past that of Ford Motor Co. and other car companies in recent days, as investors continue to bet on the growth potential of electric transportation.

title: Voters Endure Long Lines in Georgia's Primary Election
summary: Delays underscore the challenges for election officials across the country as they respond to the pandemic. Voters in Georgia's primary election Tuesday endured long lines at some voting sites, after the state adopted new voting machines and suffered shortages of poll workers because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Republicans Craft Own Police-Overhaul Proposals
summary: GOP lawmakers express interest in banning chokeholds, increasing accountability. WASHINGTON-Congressional Republicans are crafting their own proposals to respond to the killing of George Floyd while he was in police custody and the ensuing nationwide protests, marking a shift in the party's stance on overseeing police practices and raising the prospect of collaboration with Democrats.

title: George Floyd the Athlete, Classmate Remembered in Houston
summary: Dignitaries, family and friends eulogize a father and former classmate whose killing set off world-wide protests over racial injustice. HOUSTON-George Floyd was laid to rest near his mother in Houston on Tuesday, two weeks after video of his killing sparked a nationwide movement demanding racial justice and police reform.

title: GOP House Members Urge White House Not to Cut U.S. Troops in Germany
summary: 'Such steps would significantly damage U.S. national security,' 22 GOP House members write in letter to White House. WASHINGTON-Nearly two dozen Republican House members are urging the White House to reconsider its decision to cut by half the number of American troops assigned to Germany, according to a new letter.

title: Advice for CFOs on Leading in a Time of Change: Be Forthcoming
summary: Executives, policy makers and economists discussed the coronavirus pandemic and other issues during a virtual meeting hosted by The Wall Street Journal's CFO Network. Chief financial officers are steering companies through a profound period of economic and social change.

title: New York City's Homeless Population Has High Covid-19 Mortality Rate
summary: Advocates call for better shelter, free testing as the state continues reopening after months of lockdown. Advocates called on New York City and the state to better protect homeless people from Covid-19 in a report charting how the coronavirus pandemic has disproportionately affected the homeless.
